#T_SP=webanno.custom.Locationofstudy|

#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|

#Text=Principles for equitable and resilient tropical peatland restoration in Central Kalimantan, Indonesia\rTessa D Toumbourou,�Sri Lestari,�Tri WYu wati,�Sarah Treby,�Bondan Winarno,�Dony Rachmanadi,�Nafila I Idrus,�Niken Sakuntaladewi,�Kushartati Budiningsih,�Samantha P P Grover,�Andrea Rawluk\rFirst published: 22 July 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14221\rAuthor contributions: TDT, AR conceived the research and drafted the manuscript; TDT, SL, TWY, ST, BW, DR, NII, NS, KB, SPPG contributed data, analyzed the data, and edited the manuscript; AR, SPPG acquired funding and provided supervision; SPPG, NS managed project administration.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Matthias Gross\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.
#Text=Indonesia's tropical peatlands are crucial global carbon stores but have been heavily degraded in recent decades.

#Text=We present seven principles for equitable and resilient tropical peatland restoration in Central Kalimantan, Indonesia, host to 19% of Indonesia's tropical peatland area, where local livelihoods, cultural practices, and indigenous social relations remain closely connected.
#Text=Our collaborative methods employed a Delphi survey and focus group discussions with researchers from various disciplines to develop a shared vision for restoration.

#Text=This vision served as a boundary object during interviews with diverse stakeholders involved in peatland restoration in Central Kalimantan, allowing for refinement and adaptation of the vision and the development of principles to achieve it.

#Text=The principles emphasize inclusive and collaborative decision_making, planning, and implementation; site_specific approaches adapted to local social and ecological conditions; and ensuring the informed consent of and fair benefit distribution to all local social groups.

#Text=They also emphasize a holistic, integrated, and long_term approach to restoration that considers multiple aspects, including hydrological function, vegetation regeneration, fire prevention, locally appropriate livelihood benefits, inclusive governance, and adaptive management practices.

#Text=These principles serve as a starting point for resilience_oriented social_ecological restoration practice and policy formulation, aiming to facilitate equitable, effective, and resilient tropical peatland restoration outcomes.

#Text=Implications for Practice.\r* A Delphi study, combined with focus group discussions and interviews, offers a cost_effective approach to elicit geographically dispersed expert perspectives to inform a shared vision and guiding principles for social_ecological restoration _a holistic approach that tackles interconnected social and ecological issues simultaneously.\r* A shared vision served as a tangible reference to elicit constructive critique and refinement from interdisciplinary experts over a desired future state for tropical peatland restoration.\r* Experts stressed the need for tailored restoration to account for local social, ecological, and climatic conditions, as well as demographic changes and livelihood needs.\r* The principles in this study have broader applicability to social_ecological landscapes with close interaction between landscapes and livelihoods.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=In recent decades, over 5 million ha of Indonesia's peatlands have been drained, or degraded by industrial logging, palm oil, pulp wood, food estates, and associated infrastructure (Miettinen et al�2016; Dohong et al�2017), causing peatlands to become dry and prone to frequent, intensifying fires (Page et al�2009; Applegate et al�2016).
#Text=Ongoing disturbance to Indonesia's peatlands accounts for an estimated 60% of Indonesia's total greenhouse gas emissions (Applegate et al�2022).
#Text=Major national and international efforts are now targeting Indonesia's degraded peatlands for restoration (Dohong et al�2018a).

#Text=For tropical peatland restoration to succeed, an integrated approach is required, balancing ecological aspects like forest regeneration and hydrology, while ensuring food and income security and broader social well_being outcomes (Jessup et al�2020; Medrilzam et al�2017; Mishra et al�2021).

#Text=This paper focuses on Central Kalimantan, host to 2.55 Mha of peatland (19% of Indonesia's 13.43 Mha of peatland), and Kalimantan's most extensive distribution of the deepest category of peat soil thickness (defined as exceptionally very deep; >700 to >900 cm) (Anda et al�2021).
#Text=The failed Mega Rice Project in the mid_1990s, successive fires, and ongoing conversion to industrial land use has caused extensive degradation of the province's peatlands (Dohong et al�2018b).
#Text=Despite substantial restoration efforts in Central Kalimantan (eg Graham et al�2021), various challenges persist (Harrison et al�2020; Januar et al�2021; Lestari et al�2021).
#Text=These include a lack of a clear vision for restoration specific to the socio_political and ecological complexity of the region's peatlands (Puspitaloka et al�2020).

#Text=We focused on developing a shared vision and principles to guide future restoration efforts aimed at achieving equitable, effective, and resilient tropical peatland restoration in Central Kalimantan.
#Text=Theoretical Framework.

#Text=Interdisciplinary collaboration is necessary to address the social and ecological complexity of tropical peatland systems when designing interventions for social_ecological restoration (Cole et al�2021; Fleming et al�2021).
#Text=Effective interdisciplinary collaboration requires acknowledging and integrating diverse contributions from different disciplines to achieve holistic outcomes (Lyall et al�2011).

#Text=To achieve this, collaborative interdisciplinary research must focus on a common problem _in this case, degraded tropical peatlands _and apply an iterative and reflexive process (Brown et al�2019).
#Text=This requires a safe space for interaction to foster interdisciplinary thinking, to allow thinking to adapt and change, and for knowledge to build (Leslie et al�2015).
#Text=Social_ecological systems (SES) thinking recognizes the irreducible connection between social and ecological domains (Biggs et al�2015).

#Text=SES thinking understands tropical peatlands as complex systems shaped by close interactions between local people and the environment (Budiharta et al�2016); thus, their restoration must consider both the social and ecological parts of the systems; termed social_ecological restoration (Fernandez_Manjarres et al�2018).

#Text=SES thinking emphasizes that a key step in social_ecological restoration is first reaching a shared understanding of the various parts of a social ecological system (Rawluk et al�2020; Fischer et al�2021).

#Text=Shared understandings must take in diverse knowledge of how reality and knowledge are perceived, and different geographical and physical scales of focus, while navigating the power dynamics of culture, knowledge, and science (Fabinyi et al�2014).

#Text=Prioritizing the principles of SES thinking and the components of interdisciplinary collaboration, we opted for an iterative process that allows for participant anonymity to create a safe space for reflection and the development of new ideas.

#Text=In line with Puspitaloka et al's�(2020, p 435) definition of peatland restoration in Central Kalimantan; a process of assisting the recovery of degraded peatland ecosystems to achieve the appropriate trajectories defined through multi_stakeholder collaboration within social_ecological contexts, we engaged various stakeholders with diverse knowledge to collaboratively identify principles for restoring Central Kalimantan's degraded peatland ecosystems.

#Text=Following recommendations by Puspitaloka et al (2020) and other collaborative restoration research (Urgenson et al�2017; Walpole et al�2017), we initially pursued a shared vision of a desired future restoration outcome (through phases 1_3 in Fig�1�below).

#Text=The shared vision, available at Supplement�S6, served as a boundary object (Star & Griesemer�1989); a common reference point to foster and facilitate discussion between researchers from different disciplines, policymakers, and practitioners (van Rooij et al�2021).
#Text=The insights from these experts informed the principles outlined in this paper.
#Text=Figure 1\rThe four phases of our research process, their purpose, associated research activities, and results generated.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Developing a Shared Vision for Social Ecological Peatland Restoration in Indonesia.
#Text=We build on the methodology developed by Toumbourou et al (2024) to co_create a vision for restored peatlands oriented to phases of: (1) identify, (2) explore, and (3) consolidate.
#Text=We extend this with a fourth phase: (4) translate to action, to identify principles for restoration based on a shared vision (Fig�1; Supplement�S1).

#Text=A shared vision for restored peatland was developed involving Indonesian and Australian researchers participating in a 6_year research_for_development project focused on developing scientific knowledge to support Indonesia's fire control and peatland restoration practices.
#Text=We sought a strategy to involve geographically dispersed participants in a participatory manner using online technologies.

#Text=To do so, we used the Delphi method _a confidential and iterative survey method commonly used to bring experts together over a series of iterative stages to tackle complex problems where empirical data are lacking or incomplete (Lindstone & Turoff�1975; Rowe & Wright�2011).

#Text=We aimed to identify areas of shared agreement, but also capture varied views and reveal productive tensions to allow valuable insights and new knowledge to emerge (Avella�2016) (Survey questions provided at�S2�and�S4).

#Text=Informed by recent adaptations of the Delphi for qualitative research, which aim to reduce reliance on and potential bias of central moderators and promote richer insights (Fletcher & Marchildon�2014; Revez et al�2020), we integrated focus group discussions (FGDs) to involve participants in the analysis of (anonymized) themes identified from the first round of Delphi survey responses (FGD guide provided at�S3).

#Text=From Vision to Principles Specific to Central Kalimantan\rIn phase 4, we conducted semi_structured interviews with 16 people _13 Indonesian researchers, policymakers, and development practitioners, and three non_Indonesian scholars with expertise in peatland restoration in Central Kalimantan (respondent numbers in Supplement�S1).

#Text=In interviews, we presented the vision (text and/or illustrated in Supplement�S6), tailoring questions to explore specific aspects of the vision in accordance with experts' specialization (Interview guide provided at�S5).
#Text=Interview recordings were transcribed and coded using thematic analysis.
#Text=As we were working across multiple disciplines, to support validity, we cross_referenced emerging themes with relevant literature.

#Text=This paper focuses on this translation of the restoration vision into principles for achieving equitable, effective, and resilient restored peatland, contextualized to Central Kalimantan (Fig�2), developed from the data generated through our iterative methodological process.

#Text=Figure 2\rSeven principles for equitable, effective, and resilient restored tropical peatland in Central Kalimantan derived from an iterative stakeholder consultation process (Fig�1) and relevant literature.
#Text=Results.

#Text=Principles for an Equitable, Effective, and Resilient Restored Tropical Peatland in Central Kalimantan\rThe following principles and associated guidance are based on data gathered through an iterative process of soliciting expert opinion and experience (Fig�1), supplemented by relevant literature.
#Text=Tables�1_7�set out detailed guidance for each principle, and an indication of the stakeholder group these actions are relevant to.
#Text=Table 1.
#Text=�Guidance to support principle 1: prioritize sites where success is likely.
#Text=Prioritize sites where restoration is most likely to be successful, based on a thorough understanding of ecological, hydrological, and social conditions.
#Text=Tailor restoration to the specific conditions of each site, balancing social and ecological outcomes.

#Text=Analyze local ecological and social conditions\rRelevant stakeholders\ra) Understand site_specific ecology (including belowground layers such as underlying substrate, and aboveground conditions, including vegetation communities and conditions, as well as water table levels) and degradation levels, as well as social conditions (including socio_political histories and dynamics, socio_economic demographics, and past and current intra_household livelihood portfolios, and local priorities and aspirations for livelihoods and restoration).
#Text=Research, government, and community\rb) Conduct temporal and spatial assessments to consider impacts of climate change and demographic change into the future.

#Text=Research, government, and community\rZone land inclusively\rc) Ensure all stakeholders understand site ecological and social conditions, to enhance informed, collaborative land zoning decisions.
#Text=This involves ensuring all stakeholders have sufficient and accessible information (eg through the provision of user_friendly maps and models in local languages).

#Text=Research, government, and community.\rd) Identify and designate land use zones considering topography, peat depth, water flow rates, and temporal and spatial assessments to consider climate change and demographic impacts.

#Text=Prioritize high carbon stock areas for conservation including deep peat (peat with a thickness of >3 m) and remaining peat swamp forests (also crucial for seed dispersal to support natural regeneration) from further degradation (allowing local access for sustainable forest use).

#Text=Ensure adequate land in areas least exposed to flood risk is available for small_holder cultivation suitable for wet or rewetted peatlands, such as paludiculture_based agroforestry, to protect food and income security.

#Text=Research, government, and community\rTailor restoration to site conditions\re) Through multi_stakeholder platforms (MSP) established to foster genuine and meaningful collaboration with local communities (see 7a), develop a shared vision for restoration to unite stakeholders and provide a guiding framework.
#Text=Through this process, support local communities to understand their landscapes, including climate change risks and impacts, and to co_design livelihood transitions.
#Text=Research, government, and community\rf) Customize restoration approaches according to each site's socio_ecological conditions and characteristics.
#Text=Research, government, and community\rg) Begin with targeting restoration of small, easily manageable areas.

#Text=Research, government, and community\rEstablish definitions, standards, and indicators inclusively\rh) Through MSP, formulate a comprehensive social_ecological restoration framework based on understanding of ecological and social conditions.
#Text=Research, government, and community\ri.
#Text=Establish clear, holistic definitions, standards and indicators for all aspects and stages of peatland restoration.
#Text=This should include a definition of degraded peatland beyond just water table level, to also include soil moisture and vegetation cover.

#Text=Research, government, and community\rIntegrate standards and zoning designations\rj) Integrate comprehensive standards and indicators from restoration frameworks into regional peatland management plans.
#Text=Government\rAdvice from research and community\rCommunicate and enforce peatland zones and designations\rk) Communicate peatland zones and designations to all stakeholders.
#Text=Government\rAdvice from research and community\rl) Enforce peatland zones and designations.
#Text=Government, community\rTable 2 Guidance to support principle 2: block canals.

#Text=Block canals effectively using robust, sustainable materials to raise water tables and by working with land and canal users\rSupport collaborative canal blocking decisions\rRelevant stakeholders\ra) Restore hydrological functions through re_wetting landscapes by canal blocking or infilling where possible, informed by a landscape wide assessment, and local and traditional knowledge of water flows and management.

#Text=Government, development, and community\rAdvice from research\rb) Identify canal blocking and infilling sites collaboratively, considering the potential impact on the entire peatland landscape and community livelihoods (including impacts on access and cultivation practices).
#Text=Seek informed consent from, and actively engage, affected land and canal users.

#Text=Government, development, and community\rAdvice from research\rImplement resilient canal blocks that enhance livelihoods\rc) Ensure canal blocks benefit rather than restrict livelihoods, and that re_wetted conditions bring positive livelihood and well_being outcomes.
#Text=Where possible, integrate livelihood benefits into canal blocks, such as through fish cultivation in canals.
#Text=Government, development, and community\rAdvice from research\rd) Implement adaptive, locally replicable canal blocking technology using durable, sustainable materials.
#Text=Maintain access to deep peat areas for fire control, infrastructure maintenance and livelihood security via foot, motorbike, or water travel.
#Text=Ensure canal blocks facilitate market access for peatland appropriate products.

#Text=Government, development, and community\rEstablish robust and inclusive oversight processes\re) Ensure implementors and actors with oversight responsibilities have a robust understanding of the canal blocking technique they are engaged to conduct or oversee, as well as of changing water flows.

#Text=Government, development, and community\rAdvice from research\rf) Actively involve and securely employ local communities in the construction, monitoring, maintenance, and oversight of re_wetting.
#Text=Verification of project completion could involve collective signatures from local people knowledgeable about water management (rather than just a village head).

#Text=Community\rSupported by policy, development, and research\rg) Combine participatory field monitoring with remotely sensed data generated images (such as satellite remote sensing systems Landsat and Sentinel that monitor every land area on the Earth's surface and/or using unmanned aerial vehicle) of the targeted region to effectively monitor canal blocking.

#Text=Research\rInvolvement of community, government\rFund re_wetting monitoring, maintenance, and improvement ongoing\rh) Secure sufficient budget from state, bilateral countries, and innovate funding sources, to allow ongoing canal monitoring, maintenance, and improvement to ensure longevity and effectiveness of structures, and to adapt future designs.
#Text=Development, government\rTable 3.
#Text=�Guidance to support principle 3: control fires.

#Text=Prevent and suppress fires including by coordinating efforts across all stakeholders and through strategies that align with local traditional livelihood practices\rPrioritize and fund fire prevention and suppression\rRelevant stakeholders\ra.
#Text=Prioritize fire prevention and suppression.

#Text=This includes developing and integrating into existing fire management systems a peat fire danger rating system able to distinguish between non_peatland fire, peatland fire (surface only), and peat fire using remotely sensed, and ground collected data, that can communicate fire warnings to local stakeholders in locally appropriate ways (such as via radio, local television channels, phone messaging, or social media).
#Text=Government, community, and research\rSupport from development\rEnhance fire management governance\rb.
#Text=Coordinate with local communities to select and publicize the locations of wells.

#Text=This could include communication through various forms (such as accessible maps on village notice boards or information exchanges in culturally appropriate forums, such as language or cultural groups of all women and all men).
#Text=Community, government, and development\rAdvice from research\rc.
#Text=Improve the contracting process for fire prevention infrastructure.
#Text=Government\rSupport from development\rd.
#Text=Improve government mechanisms to release budget allocations for fire prevention and suppression prior to fires.
#Text=Government\rSupport from development\re.
#Text=Ensure firefighting equipment is available and sufficient.
#Text=Government\rSupport from development\rEnhance infrastructure oversight\rf.
#Text=Improve oversight of deep well construction to ensure that wells are built in locations where water access is needed and to a sufficient depth.
#Text=Government, community\rSupport from development\rAdvice from research\rTable 4.
#Text=�Guidance to support principle 4: adapt revegetation to conditions.

#Text=Adjust revegetation strategies to the changing conditions of natural regeneration and hydrological functions at the target site, taking into account community food and income_earning needs and priorities.
#Text=Plan regeneration with consideration of landscapes and livelihoods\rRelevant stakeholders\ra.
#Text=Protect and maintain remnant peat swamp forest.
#Text=Government, community\rSupport from development\rAdvice from research\rb.
#Text=Prioritize unassisted/natural regeneration of local, endemic species where possible, while continuing water table maintenance, weeding, and fire prevention of regenerating sites.
#Text=Government, community, and development\rAdvice from research\rc.
#Text=Where assisted revegetation is necessary, ensure the soil is sufficiently moist prior to planting local, endemic species.
#Text=The use of fungi inoculants can help stimulate growth, especially where mycorrhizal fungi have been depleted.
#Text=Government, community, and development\rAdvice from research\rd.
#Text=Where appropriate, such as in buffer zones or over commons land near residential areas, revegetate with species that have livelihood benefits, as identified by local communities.
#Text=Collaboration between community and government\rSupport from development\rAdvice from research\rEstablish inclusive practices, including monitoring and oversight\re.

#Text=Involve the community in all stages of revegetation, from species selection (including species that offer food, medicinal, or other livelihood benefits), to monitoring of species survivorship and other key variables.
#Text=Community\rAdvice from research,\rSupport from development and government\rTable 5.
#Text=�Guidance to support principle 5: ensure consensual participation.
#Text=Ensure that local communities' active participation is genuine, empowering and based on informed consent.
#Text=Secure informed, ongoing consent and active engagement of local communities\rRelevant stakeholders\ra.
#Text=Use participatory methods to identify who lives on and relies on sites identified for restoration, as well as those affected by upstream, downstream, and indirect changes.
#Text=Secure informed and ongoing consent from all social groups in a community prior to any restoration intervention.
#Text=Collaboration between research, development, and community\rSupport from government\rb.
#Text=Ensure participation is genuine and does not place further burden on local communities.
#Text=Employ local women and men as focal points to communicate between village social groups and other stakeholders.
#Text=Provide adequate and locally appropriate compensation to each individual where participation requires taking time away from livelihood activities.
#Text=Collaboration between research, development, and community\rSupport from government\rc.
#Text=Ensure that local communities have full understanding of, and control over the decisions for each component of restoration.
#Text=Collaboration between research, development, and community\rSupport from government\rTable 6.
#Text=�Guidance to support principle 6: benefit livelihoods and well_being.
#Text=Ensure that restoration improves livelihoods and well_being sustainably for all villagers, including through improved market reach and savings mechanisms.
#Text=Ensure restoration delivers genuine livelihood and well_being benefits\rRelevant stakeholders\ra.
#Text=Ensure restoration activities fairly and equitably deliver social and economic benefits to local communities, including secure, waged employment opportunities.
#Text=Support local services or infrastructure to supply basic needs, including drinking water treatment technologies, household solar energy arrays, and access to the internet.
#Text=Collaboration between research, development, and communities\rSupport from government\rb.

#Text=Identify and promote appropriate livelihood options suitable for wet or rewetted peat conditions in Central Kalimantan in parallel with changes triggered by ecological restoration that also align with the diverse knowledges, experiences, and aspirations of different local social groups.
#Text=Provide financial support and seedlings for paludiculture crops identified by local women and men.
#Text=Collaboration between research, development, and communities\rSupport from government\rc.
#Text=Prioritize upscaling and value_adding to wet or rewet peat_appropriate livelihood activities, including improved producer prices for paludiculture products.
#Text=Develop financial services (such as micro_loans and credit unions) and support the formation of village cooperatives.
#Text=Provide product processing and storage facilities, and renewable energy to power them.
#Text=Development, government, communities\rAdvice from research\rd.
#Text=Provide mentoring, support, and training and demonstrate new innovations by working with local champions experimenting with new livelihood options.
#Text=Collaboration between research, development, and communities\rSupport from government\rEstablish and apply locally meaningful indicators\re.
#Text=With communities, develop locally meaningful indicators for monitoring the impact of livelihood interventions.
#Text=Apply these indicators to monitor and evaluate livelihood benefits ongoing.
#Text=Use assessment results to adapt interventions to continually enhance livelihood outcomes.
#Text=Collaboration between research, and communities\rProvide advice to government\rTable 7.
#Text=�Guidance to support principle 7: establish collaborative governance.
#Text=Establish collaborative and holistic governance and management that caters to multiple functions, actors, needs and interests.
#Text=Enhance inclusive governance and practice adaptive, long_term management\rRelevant stakeholders\ra.
#Text=Enhance collaboration and coordination between stakeholders through sub_national multi_stakeholder platforms (MSP).

#Text=MSP could involve small, interdisciplinary networks that meet regularly (to develop a sense of trust) in person or virtually, with the aim of creating a shared understanding of a system, to identify their joint sphere of action, and to map out the roles, rights, and functions of different stakeholders.
#Text=Development, government, communities, and research\rb.
#Text=Clarify land tenure and ownership equitably.
#Text=Engage local (including customary) bodies that hold rights or decision_making over shared village or community land.

#Text=Ensure land ownership formalization (ie land titles or certificates) registers the names of all land_claiming individuals within households, not just the (commonly male) household head, to avoid excluding women.
#Text=Government, community\rAdvice from research\rSupport from development\rHarmonize policies\rc.
#Text=Align state policies to support restoration.
#Text=Harmonize spatial plans with national and sub_national development plans, and remove policies and subsidies (such as for plantation expansion) that drive peatland degradation.
#Text=Clarify and enforce sanctions or administrative warnings for regulatory non_compliance.
#Text=Government\rAdvice from research, community, and development\rd.
#Text=Consider the long_term considerations, cross_cutting risks, and impacts of climate change in spatial planning.
#Text=Research\rAdvice to government and community\rPractice adaptive management responding to monitoring\re.
#Text=Conduct community_based restoration monitoring of hydrological, vegetational, and livelihood outcomes.

#Text=On the Peatland Restoration Information and Monitoring System (PRISM), make publicly accessible high_quality and fine_scale maps (for research purposes) and include the location and maintenance updates (the results of community_based monitoring) of physical restoration infrastructure, revegetation and livelihood support, and the results of peatland research and interventions.
#Text=Explore digital mapping methods to assess peat thickness and estimate carbon stock.
#Text=Communities, government, and research\rf.
#Text=Practice adaptive management informed by local and traditional knowledge systems and the results of monitoring and evaluation.
#Text=Government, development, and community\rAdvice from research\rFund restoration ongoing\rg.
#Text=Ensure peatland restoration projects' duration and funding reflect the time required for peatland restoration.
#Text=In addition to government budgets, explore new flexible and longer_term funding options, including development sector (including bilateral donor countries) and private sector funding.
#Text=Government, development.

#Text=Principle 1 Prioritize Sites Where Success Is Likely (see Table�1)\rA lack of clarity or agreement around standards, definitions, and goals for peatland restoration in Indonesia inhibits effective practice and monitoring (respondents 1, 2, 5, 9, and 16) (Ward et al�2020).
#Text=The Indonesian government has established regulations that classify peat ecosystems based on peat thickness, designating them as either suitable for cultivation or protection.

#Text=Peat ecosystems with a thickness of more than 3 meters are designated for protection, while those with a thickness of less than 3 meters are designated for cultivation (Minister of Environment and Forestry Regulation no. 57 of 2016, article 9).
#Text=These classifications have different quality measures for triggering restoration.

#Text=Peatland designated for cultivation is considered damaged, and thus requiring restoration, if the groundwater level is higher than  0.4 meters below the peat surface and/or pyrite and/or quartz sediments beneath the peat layer are exposed.

#Text=Peatland designated for protection is considered damaged, and thus requiring restoration, if there is artificial drainage present; pyrite and/or quartz sediments are exposed; and/or there is a reduction in the area and/or volume of land cover.

#Text=Broadening this quality measure out to include soil moisture and vegetation cover is necessary _as a higher water table increases soil moisture (Jaenicke et al�2010) which in turn influences natural vegetation regeneration (Triisberg et al�2013) _encompassing all integrated components required for eco_hydrological restoration (Mishra et al�2021; Wosten et al�2008).

#Text=The development of standards, definitions, and goals should actively involve all affected local social groups (ie men and women of all ages, ethnicities, socio_economic positions, as well as those with different priorities for landscapes), as local people are most likely to enact and sustain restoration if it offers them meaningful, beneficial outcomes (respondent 5) (Jessup et al�2020; Purnomo et al�2024).

#Text=Sites targeted for restoration should be based on a thorough understanding of the socio_political dynamics, ecological conditions, and disturbance histories (frequent burning, inundation, or the existence of canals) of both the immediate site and the adjacent area (respondents 2 and 15) (Graham et al�2017).

#Text=Highly degraded areas, including oxidized, dehydrated deep peat, may require intensive restoration over a long period and may never fully regain their natural hydrological or ecological functions (Graham et al�2017; Hansson & Dargusch�2018), and thus will require different indicators for measuring restoration progress.
#Text=Restoration plans are more effective when tailored to local conditions, as these will require different restoration processes (respondent 2) (Graham et al�2017).

#Text=Prioritizing restoring small, easily manageable areas for early success will help to create a foundation for scalable projects where local communities are supportive (respondent 8) (Purnomo et al�2024).

#Text=Restoration frameworks could be established through forming multi_stakeholder platforms (Tengberg et al�2021) that facilitate constructive collaboration and the co_production of knowledge, including the development of a shared vision for restoration at the district and provincial levels to inform cohesive restoration and align conflicting policies (respondents 5, 7, and 10).
#Text=Tropical peatland units are highly variable, each requiring different access and use designations and restoration strategies (Applegate et al�2022; Purnomo et al�2024).
#Text=Categorizing peatland areas and determining use and access rights should be based on collaborative planning and decision_making, involving all local social groups (respondents 7 and 8).

#Text=Effective land zoning relies on site_specific information about social and ecological conditions, and temporal and spatial assessments of the impacts of climate change and population projections (respondents 1, 10, and 15).

#Text=This information should be made accessible to all stakeholders to allow active engagement in land zoning decisions (Jessup et al�2020), foster better understanding of peatland landscapes, and dispel misconceptions, such as the belief that canals improve irrigation (respondents 1 and 12).

#Text=Currently, only peatland areas with peat deeper than 3 m are zoned for protection (from conversion to other land uses, such as industrial plantations), even if other sites with shallower peat have high socio_ecological and biodiversity value (Dohong et al�2018a).

#Text=Safeguarding areas with greater carbon stocks, including deep peat (>3 m) and remaining peat swamp forests (crucial for seed dispersal to support natural regeneration), from further degradation must be a land zoning priority (respondents 1 and 14) (Mishra et al�2021).

#Text=To generate sufficient food and viable incomes, sustainable livelihood activities, such as controlled fishing, and the harvesting of non_timber forest products, should be allowed in conservation areas, while smallholder cultivation activities appropriate for wet and rewetted peatlands should be zoned over shallow peat and mineral soils at the edge of peat domes (respondents 1, 2, 3, 7, 10, 12, 14, and 15) (Surahman et al�2018; Applegate et al�2022).

#Text=Smallholder farming on shallow peat (except for paludiculture), may not be sustainable into the future due to increasing flood risk resulting from climate change and peat subsidence (respondents 1 and 16).

#Text=Collaborative land zoning must ensure that local communities understand these risks and impacts, and livelihood transition plans should be developed and implemented together with local communities (see principle 7) (respondent 7).
#Text=Principle 2 Block Canals (See Table�2)\rRe_establishing hydrological function is essential for effective peatland restoration (respondents 1, 8, and 9).
#Text=This involves constructing canal blocks to reduce rates of drainage, aiming to rewet adjacent peatland ecosystems (Dohong et al�2018a).

#Text=Infilling canals, where feasible, could both aid rewetting by slowing outflows and raising sedimentation levels within the canal to minimize drainage (Dohong et al�2018a), and, following revegetation, increase habitat provisioning (respondent 10).
#Text=However, challenges arise in ensuring the effectiveness, durability, and community acceptance of canal blocking and infilling efforts.

#Text=Canals in peatland areas have been used by local communities to drain and dry peat soils for agricultural use, and as a means of transport to access areas of peatland to support their livelihoods and reach markets (Harrison et al�2020).

#Text=Numerous canal blocking projects have been undertaken, yet their effectiveness has varied and is hindered by physical collapse and disintegration due to: fire, poor design, or low durability materials (such as those constructed from peat or wood).
#Text=Additionally, some local communities have damaged or destroyed canal blocks that limit their access to livelihood resources (respondents 1, 6, and 8).
#Text=To ensure longevity, canal blocks should be constructed using durable, high_quality materials (Page et al�2009; Jaenicke et al�2010).

#Text=The location of physical rewetting infrastructure must consider the entire landscape, including hydrology and topography, and draw on local and traditional knowledge of peatland flows and management (respondents 2 and 7).

#Text=Free, informed, and ongoing consent (see Principle 5) must be secured from canal users or owners, and access to deep peat areas must be maintained to support fire control, infrastructure maintenance, and livelihoods (respondents 1, 7, 8, 14, and 15).
#Text=Canal blocking is about balancing the ground water levels (respondent 7) and must consider site flow volumes (respondents 6 and 14).

#Text=Challenges include a lack of understanding of canal block design's intricacies among contractors (respondents 6, 7, and 8), insufficient oversight in the canal blocking process, including auditing of contractor deliverables, and unclear distribution of funding and responsibility between government agencies (Pantau Gambut�2019).
#Text=In some instances, local communities have been left to maintain rewetting infrastructure without funding, technology, or clarity over their role (Pantau Gambut�2019).
#Text=Training and employing local communities to be involved in all aspects of canal block construction, monitoring, and management will enhance rewetting outcomes.
#Text=Budget constraints and inflexible timelines further impede restoration efforts (respondents 6 and 7).

#Text=Budgets for canal blocking come primarily from the national budget, which must be allocated and spent within a fiscal year (respondent 7), limiting flexibility for longer_term projects _particularly community engagement, landscape assessments, and monitoring.
#Text=Confirming project completion has often relied on a village head's signature, who may not understand the project's design or effectiveness (respondent 9).
#Text=Accountability could be improved through verification involving collective signatures or local people knowledgeable about water management (respondent 2).
#Text=Canal blocks must be monitored and maintained to ensure they effectively support ongoing rewetting.
#Text=Evaluating canal blocking effectiveness requires assessing peat moisture levels prior to intervention, alongside fluctuations in rainfall (Mishra et al�2021).

#Text=Where possible, participatory field methods should be prioritized to assess groundwater levels, soil moisture, and peat subsidence (Okarda et al�2023), ensure monitoring accuracy, grant scientific validity to local knowledge of landscapes for integration into scientific knowledge production, and inform adaptive management (Terzano et al�2022; Purnomo et al�2024).

#Text=Multi_source open_access remotely sensed data could supplement these assessments (Jaenicke et al�2010; Kameoka et al�2021; Czapiewski & Szumi ska�2022), providing robust, ground_verified assessments of rewetting and accounting for seasonal variation (Mishra et al�2021).

#Text=Principle 3 Control Fires (See Table�3)\rThe drainage of peatlands alters peat structure, resulting in the dominance of ferns, grasses, and shrubs, and increased tree falls, which become fuel for fires when dry (Page et al�2009; Graham et al�2017).
#Text=Successive fires increase peatland susceptibility to fire, hindering forest regeneration (Page & Hooijer�2016).
#Text=Despite their importance, fire prevention and suppression have not been a primary restoration focus (Uda et al�2020a; Terzano et al�2022).
#Text=Blanket bans on fire use for land clearing are costly for smallholders to comply with (Silvianingsih et al�2021).
#Text=Some bans have exacerbated food insecurity and livelihood precarity, leading to land abandonment and complicating fire control (Nurhidayah et al�2023).
#Text=Support is required for local farmers to transition to sustainable food security and livelihood alternatives (respondent 14).

#Text=A community_based fire management approach is needed that coordinates across all stakeholders, draws on local and traditional knowledge of local conditions and fire hazards (respondent 14) (Purnomo et al�2024), and that actively involves local communities in decision_making about fire control (Nurhidayah et al�2023).

#Text=This could include incorporating into Indonesia's existing fire danger rating system an accurate peat fire danger rating system that communicates fire risks accessibly and effectively across diverse communities to ensure successful fire prevention and management (Graham et al�2021; Robins et al�2022).
#Text=Despite being dangerous and demanding work, firefighting in Central Kalimantan relies on local volunteers; Masyarakat Peduli Api (MPA; Community Fire Brigades).

#Text=In some villages, MPA volunteers receive only temporary payment from village funds (during the dry season), falling short of their actual costs and time away from livelihood activities, and their compensation has not kept up with increased demands (respondent 4).

#Text=In some instances, MPA volunteers have been provided with a community livelihood benefit_sharing arrangement (such as livestock, fish, or crop cultivation) that may not align with their preferences or experience (respondent 4).
#Text=Funding shortages and bureaucratic hurdles obstruct access to firefighting equipment (respondent 4).
#Text=Many local governments lack sufficient budgets for fire mitigation (Budiningsih et al�2022; Nurhidayah et al�2023).

#Text=Better understanding and utilization of government budget sources, such as village budgets (Dana Desa) and Reforestation Revenue Sharing funds (DBH DR), could support fire prevention (respondent 14).

#Text=Deep wells are a key infrastructure funded by the Indonesian government (through the Peatland and Mangrove Restoration Agency [BRGM]) for firefighting, yet their construction and maintenance face challenges.
#Text=Lack of public knowledge about well locations limits their use and maintenance (respondent 5).
#Text=Additionally, some wells are not deep enough to provide water (respondents 4 and 6).

#Text=Tendering and contracting arrangements for well building (and other restoration physical infrastructure) are often rushed to meet government budget deadlines, and oversight and maintenance budgets are insufficient (respondent 6).
#Text=Pumps for accessing well water are heavy and difficult to transport, adding to the challenge of using wells for firefighting.
#Text=Ensuring wells are strategically located and accessible, along with implementing robust oversight (involving local communities), is vital to ensure they support fire suppression.

#Text=Principle 4 Adapt Revegetation to Conditions (see Table�4)\rFollowing rewetting, revegetation should be carried out with endemic local species to enhance biodiversity, rebuild the upper layer of peat soil with plant roots and litter, stabilize microclimates, and reduce fire risk (respondent 9) (Mishra et al�2021).
#Text=Canal blocking (Principle 2) has been shown to raise the water table and initiate the recovery of native peatland vegetation (Hooijer et al�2024).

#Text=Some previous revegetation efforts have not succeeded due to inadequate hydrological restoration leading to plant loss in peatland fires (respondent 8), or a limited understanding of peatland plant ecology (Mishra et al�2021).

#Text=On less degraded peatlands, natural regeneration can be more successful (and cost_efficient) than assisted planting, as naturally emerging seedlings are better acclimated to the landscape (respondent 14) (Graham et al�2013).

#Text=Nonetheless, natural regeneration still requires some maintenance of water tables, and, depending on landscape conditions, weeding to control ground cover (Blackham et al�2014; Graham et al�2017).
#Text=Natural regeneration may only be feasible in close proximity (within 500 m) to closed_canopy, mature forests, beyond which seed dispersal is limited (Wijedasa et al�2020).
#Text=Enrichment planting may be needed to increase forest diversity where endemic species regrowth is rare or mature forests are distant.
#Text=Highly degraded areas typically require fully assisted revegetation to protect planted seedlings (Blackham et al�2014; Graham et al�2017).
#Text=The use of fungi inoculants in planted species can help stimulate growth, especially where mycorrhizal fungi have been lost (Yuwati & Putri�2020; Yuwati & Hakim�2023).

#Text=To prevent acid sulfate production (which is toxic to plants) from oxidation of pyrite in shallow peat or underlying substrate (respondent 12), it is crucial to keep pyrite layers anoxic under water via careful hydrological management (Sakuntaladewi et al�2022).

#Text=Monitoring and supervision, particularly of assisted or enrichment planting, is important to ensure tree seedlings survive weather extremes and competition from existing plant communities (respondent 14) (Blackham et al�2014).

#Text=Revegetation projects require funding for ongoing monitoring, maintenance, and the active involvement of local communities to assess plant survival rates and replace seedlings that do not survive (respondent 16) (Harrison et al�2023).
#Text=In areas near settlements, restoring endemic forest species should be balanced with planting trees that provide livelihood benefits, such as fruit trees (respondent 8) (Dommain et al�2016).
#Text=Moreover, local communities should be securely employed in revegetation work, including monitoring revegetation outcomes (respondent 8).
#Text=Principle 5.

#Text=Ensure Consensual Participation (see Table�5)\rHistorically, central governing agencies have dominated peatland restoration, lacking effective community involvement due to limited time, budget, and engagement practices.
#Text=This has led to low support for, and a weak sense of ownership over, restoration processes locally (respondent 7) (Ward et al�2020).
#Text=In some instances, engagement has been limited to local elites who have not distributed information and funding equitably within their communities (Harrison et al�2020).

#Text=Projects that fail to account for communities' differentiated needs and values or that ineffectively compensate local labor have struggled to sustain community support (Wiesner & Dargusch�2022).

#Text=Securing the free, informed, and ongoing consent of land users and rights holders, with independent oversight, is crucial to avoid negative outcomes such as displacement or opposition (Wiesner & Dargusch�2022).

#Text=Participatory methods can help identify who lives on and relies on, sites identified for restoration, as well as those affected by upstream, downstream, and indirect changes (Fleischman et al�2022; Purnomo et al�2024).
#Text=Gaining informed consent must fit alongside (and not at the expense of) the other pressures of daily life or compensate participants for time away from livelihood activities (Elias et al�2022).
#Text=All affected groups should understand each step of the restoration process and its implications to actively participate in decisions (respondents 5, 6, and 16) (Ward et al�2020).

#Text=Collaboration with communities should involve reaching a shared understanding of and a pathway to achieving desired restored peatland conditions, employing local village facilitators as focal points who understand the real daily issues [the community] faces (respondent 7).
#Text=Adequate resources and funding are necessary for sustained community participation, including youth and indigenous groups (respondents 2 and 7).
#Text=Monitoring must involve local women and men alongside practitioners and researchers to continuously evaluate success and inform the adaptation of practice (respondent 15) (Elias et al�2022).
#Text=Principle 6.

#Text=Benefit Livelihoods and Well_Being (See Table�6)\rPeatland degradation and deforestation since the 1970s have led to high poverty levels, necessitating restoration efforts to bring social, economic, and livelihood benefits to affected communities (respondents 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 8, 12, and 16) (Suyanto et al�2009).

#Text=Sustainable livelihoods are needed that adapt to changing soil conditions as a result of raised water tables (Principle 2), and to transition away from activities with negative ecological impacts, such as charcoal generation and palm oil cultivation (respondents 7, 8, 9, and 14).
#Text=Livelihood interventions should be measured against locally defined indicators of well_being (respondent 9) (Woodhouse et al�2015).

#Text=Basic water, renewable energy (to reduce reliance on charcoal), and internet access are essential for communities residing in landscapes targeted for restoration, to improve well_being, and increase information sharing about restoration and product processing to get a higher market price (respondents 3, 8, 13, and 16) (Salminah et al�2021).

#Text=Paludiculture_based agroforestry, a system of smallholder farming involving a diverse mix of faster and slower growing crops suitable for natural and re_wetted peatlands, shows promise for enhancing smallholder resilience and profitability (respondents 5 and 16) (Budiman et al�2020; Uda et al�2020b).

#Text=Low_maintenance crops like Purun (Lepironia articulata) can deliver a substantial and dense yield, and its hand_woven products have established markets that could be further enhanced (respondents 7, 12, and 13) (Itta et al�2021).

#Text=Beekeeping of Kelutut stingless honeybees (Trigona�sp.) for honey can complement other income sources, such as Jelutung (Dyera costulata) trees tapped for latex (respondents 4, 6, 10, and 14) (Yuwati et al�2021).
#Text=Other options include duck and fish farming, and eco_, cultural_, or agro_tourism (such as fruit picking) (respondents 5, 10, 12, 15, and 16).

#Text=Crops or commodities grown over natural or re_wetted peatlands elsewhere in Indonesia offer examples of where rewetting has increased yields (such as in coconut farming) (respondents 2, 6, 10, and 14).
#Text=Enhancing the quality and market reach of products suitable for wet or rewetted peatlands should be prioritized (respondents 5, 6, and 10).
#Text=Current limitations stem from small_scale production and market control issues (such as cartel dominance) (respondent 6) (Miller�2022).
#Text=Assistance is needed to address value chain issues, increase market access, and enhance processing locally (respondent 7).
#Text=Financial services and storage facilities may help to buffer against periods of low yield or income loss, and clusters or village cooperatives could elevate product prices (respondent 7).

#Text=Mentorship, support, and training are needed alongside demonstration of new livelihood options from local people already adopting novel options (respondent 2), as well as through seedling provision and local financial support (Uda et al�2020a).

#Text=Prices for local products can be increased through processing products to supply local and international markets (such as creating butters or oils from illipe nuts), but further support (including energy, infrastructure, and administration) is needed to do so (respondents 7, 12, and 16) (Giesen & Sari�2018).

#Text=Local communities should be trained and employed to conduct all aspects of restoration as much as possible but must not be exploited through inadequate resources or labor conditions (respondents 4, 9, and 12).
#Text=Principle 7.

#Text=Establish Collaborative Governance (See Table�7)\rThe government's role is critical to ensure that policies align and are synchronized from the central to the local level to ensure effective peatland restoration (respondent 7).
#Text=Relevant regulations for peatland use and management must be harmonized and communicated appropriately to each stakeholder group (Januar et al�2021).
#Text=Implementing agencies require sufficient and aligned budgets, objectives, and timelines (respondent 9).

#Text=Coordination across peatland hydrological units and wider landscapes is challenging due to Indonesia's fragmented land administration involving multiple line ministries and government agencies at different levels with authority for different land or forest types, including many with overlapping authority for peatland (respondents 5, 7, 9, and 10) (Sahide & Giessen�2015).

#Text=This lack of coordination means that local governments and communities may not know about the development planned for their region; For example, road building appears out of nowhere� Or, suddenly, there's a canal (respondent 10).
#Text=Inconsistencies between the regulations and approaches of ministries and institutions that govern peatlands impede restoration efforts.

#Text=Within the BRGM, distinct targets and responsibilities of the three administrative divisions of restoration, known as the Three R's _rewetting, revegetation, and revitalization of livelihoods _have made coordination and planning challenging (respondent 9).
#Text=New, more integrated approaches, however, show promise.
#Text=Improved cohesion between BRGM units and collaboration with provincial and district governments are necessary for effective restoration policy integration (respondents 9 and 12).

#Text=Multi_stakeholder platforms and sub_national entities for coordination across peatdomes could support mapping out the roles, rights, and functions of each stakeholder, and identifying and implementing a shared vision for peatland restoration (respondents 7 and 10).

#Text=So far, peatland has not been well integrated into spatial plans; In some areas, land is zoned for cultivation, even though it is an area of deep peat and not suitable for cultivation (respondent 15).

#Text=Peatland restoration policy must be spatially explicit to protect areas of deep peat and remaining peat swamp forests and should consider the inherent interconnectedness of peat hydrological systems (respondent 2).

#Text=Spatial plans must be harmonized with national and sub_national development plans, and policies and subsidies that drive peatland degradation, such as plantation expansion, must be removed to avoid further degradation (respondents 7, 10, and 15).

#Text=The Peatland Restoration Information and Monitoring System (PRIMS;�https://prims.brgm.go.id/platform) integrates data on peatlands and restoration interventions, including canal blocks, deep wells, revegetation, and village livelihood support activities (�Peat Care Villages�) across seven provinces, including Central Kalimantan, at 1:50,000 scale.
#Text=While it lacks updates on physical infrastructure conditions, vegetation type, or maintenance, PRIMS holds potential for enhanced transparency in monitoring peatland restoration.

#Text=Emerging digital mapping methods offer cost_effective assessment of peat thickness and carbon stock estimates (Rudiyanto et al�2018; Ill�s et al�2019) to complement field monitoring of hydrological, vegetation, and livelihood outcomes (respondents 1, 5, and 13).

#Text=For improved transparency and local scrutiny, peat spatial data, updates of maintenance and ongoing monitoring results of restoration projects, and the results of restoration research efforts must be publicly accessible and comprehensible to all stakeholders (respondents 1, 5, and 16).
#Text=Land tenure clarity is vital to make clear who has authority and incentive to participate in peatland restoration (respondent 1) (Elias et al�2022).

#Text=Currently, 60% of smallholder farmers in Central Kalimantan lack the highest level of land ownership certificate (Uda et al�2020a), due to financial and legal hurdles to registration (Sanders et al�2019).
#Text=As a result, identifying land use and ownership is difficult, posing challenges for consultation, consent, and compensation (respondents 1, 7, 8, and 15).
#Text=To enable and encourage local people to invest in landscapes in the longer_term, land tenure must be clarified and strengthened for all women and men.

#Text=As the region's peatlands have long histories of shared use and access, restoration efforts must recognize and respect community rights over commonly held village or community land, and the local bodies or decision_making processes that manage these (Elias et al�2021).

#Text=Most projects in Central Kalimantan are based on grants or programs that last only 5_10 years or, at most, 15 years, far shorter than the 20_to_50_year commitment required (respondents 1, 5, 6, 7, and 8).
#Text=Similarly, peatland restoration is expensive, and the true cost and time required for restoration are often underestimated (Hansson & Dargusch�2018).
#Text=Government budget constraints impede what can be funded and when, hindering restoration progress (respondent 15).

#Text=When restoration projects conclude, if their social aspects (such as support for livelihood activities) are not continued and engineering structures are not maintained, progress is lost (respondents 7 and 8).

#Text=New flexible funding options are needed to support long_term restoration _such as from bilateral donor countries, the private sector, financial institutions, or nature_based solution markets (respondents 7, 8, 13, and 15) (Puspitaloka et al�2021).

#Text=Enforcement mechanisms, such as sanctions or administrative warnings for non_compliance, should be clarified and enforced, such as for palm oil companies not monitoring groundwater levels in their permit concession areas (respondents 6 and 9).
#Text=While many components are relevant throughout the restoration process, in Table�8, we suggest the components of each principle most relevant at each restoration stage.
#Text=Table 8.
#Text=�Phases of the restoration process and corresponding components of each principle.

#Text=Phases of restoration\rDesign\rImplementation\rMonitoring, evaluation, and oversight\rThroughout\rPrinciple 1: prioritize sites where success is likely\rAnalyze local ecological and social conditions (a, b)\rZone land inclusively (c, d)\rTailor restoration to site conditions (e_g)\rEstablish definitions, standards, and indicators inclusively (h, i)\rIntegrate standards and zoning designations (j)\r\rCommunicate and enforce zones and designations (k, l)\rPrinciple 2: Block canals\rSupport collaborative canal blocking decisions (a, b)\rImplement resilient canal blocks that benefit livelihoods (c, d)\rEstablish robust and inclusive oversight processes (e_g)\rFund re_wetting monitoring, maintenance, and improvement ongoing (h)\rPrinciple 3: Control fires\rPrioritize and fund fire prevention and suppression (a)\rEnhance fire management governance (b_e)\rEnhance infrastructure oversight (f)\r\rPrinciple 4: Adapt revegetation to conditions\r\rRegenerate with consideration of landscapes and livelihoods (a_d)\rEstablish inclusive practice, including monitoring and oversight (e)\r\rPrinciple 5: Ensure consensual participation\r\rSecure informed, ongoing consent, and active engagement of local communities (a_c)\r\r\rPrinciple 6: Benefit livelihoods and well_being\r\rEnsure restoration delivers genuine livelihood and well_being benefits (a_d)\rEstablish and apply locally meaningful indicators (e)\r\rPrinciple 7: Establish collaborative governance\rEnhance inclusive governance and practice adaptive, long_term management (a, b)\rHarmonize policies (c, d)\rPractice adaptive management responding to monitoring (e, f)\rFund restoration ongoing (g)\rDiscussion.
#Text=Together the seven principles highlight the importance of continuing to support transdisciplinary collaboration throughout restoration practices.

#Text=Our process of first identifying a desirable future state in the form of a shared vision helped to provide a foundation and tangible entry point for expert consultation, who provided nuanced detail to particular parts or dimensions of the vision and identified strategies to transition from the current state to the desirable future state (Wiek & Iwaniec�2014).

#Text=In this way, a shared vision serves as a boundary object _plastic enough to accommodate local needs and different conceptual perspectives, yet robust enough to facilitate meaningful dialogue and convey coherent perspectives across diverse disciplines and scales, in pursuit of a common purpose (Star�2010).

#Text=Following a process of first identifying a vision is beneficial for any social_ecological restoration project, as it brings stakeholders together to reach agreement around the parts of a restored social_ecological system, before developing a process for achieving the vision.
#Text=The process of working from a vision is, however, not without challenges _taking the shared vision to experts revealed many of the shortcomings and challenges to achieving the vision.
#Text=As interdisciplinary researchers, we recognize the need to be open to changing our understanding and adapting our methods and approaches (Haeffner et al�2022).

#Text=The principles reinforce the importance of engaging with restoration as an interconnected social_ecological challenge, such as through SES thinking, to observe and engage with, the complex and entangled relationships between social, political, and ecological parts of a tropical peatland system.
#Text=Furthermore, the principles highlight the importance of grappling with ecological and institutional scales, such as localized nuances and conditions (Budiharta et al�2016).

#Text=The principles also recognize that local and traditional communities hold complex knowledge of the landscapes from which they have long derived their livelihoods (Uprety et al�2012), which should be centered on every aspect of restoration.
#Text=Reflecting the complexity of social_ecological restoration, these ambitious principles may not all be immediately feasible.
#Text=Many of the components align with practices already applied in different places and scales in Indonesia, including those embedded within government restoration plans.
#Text=Our principles also align with broader scholarship advocating for social_ecological restoration approaches prioritizing social equity, effectiveness, and resilience.

#Text=This includes addressing social justice and inclusion (Elias et al�2022; Fleischman et al�2022) and ensuring ecological effectiveness and long_term resilience through diversity, connectivity, and adaptability (Biggs et al�2012; Fischer et al�2021).
#Text=Corroborating other scholarship, cross_cutting the seven principles is an emphasis on inclusivity, collaboration, and coordination among stakeholders.

#Text=Ensuring the informed consent of and collaboration with local communities throughout each stage of restoration is essential, though time consuming, as it leads to sustained outcomes and improved quality of life where restoration aligns with local preferences and priorities (Elias et al�2022).
#Text=Short_term, inflexible approaches with little community involvement have often failed.

#Text=Other themes include adapting site_specific approaches to local social and ecological conditions, and adopting a holistic, integrated approach considering hydrological functions, vegetation regeneration, fire prevention, locally appropriate livelihood priorities, inclusive governance, and long_term, adaptive management practices.

#Text=Restoration must aim for sustainable and long_lasting ecological and social outcomes and resilience, recognizing that peatlands and local people's livelihoods will continue to face diverse changes, ranging from climate impacts to evolving markets and aspirations (Sigman & Elias�2021).

#Text=Future steps involve adapting our two_phase approach of co_creating a shared vision and guiding principles toward implementation in a co_design process with local communities in peatland areas to ensure that the principles are meaningful and locally relevant.

#Text=Acknowledgments\rThis study was conducted as part of Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) funded project FST/2016/144 Improving community fire management and peatland restoration in Indonesia.
#Text=Funding AUD $301,593.
#Text=We thank each of the participants involved in the Delphi survey, the focus group discussions, and the interviews.
